title: Collisions - elastic collision of two objects

content.question: Object <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> and Object <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> of mass <math alttext="3 m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mi>m</mi></math> can slide along a straight, horizontal track with negligible friction. Object <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> initially moves to the right with speed <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> toward Object <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, which is initially at rest, and the two objects collide. Immediately after the collision, Object <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> moves to the left with speed <math alttext="the fraction v over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle></math>. Is this information sufficient to determine whether the collision was elastic? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes, because the fact that the velocity of Object <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> changed direction during the collision means that the collision was not elastic.

Yes, because conservation of momentum can be used to determine the final speed of Object <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, and the total kinetic energy of the two-object system after the collision can be calculated.
No, because the final speed of Object <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> cannot be determined without knowing whether the collision was elastic or inelastic.
No, because the collision can be elastic for many different values of the final speed of Object <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.
